resources.string: White border between buttons and questionnaire
There were also some red flag symptoms
We\'ve prepared some resources for people who want to learn more about depression

Depression affects hundreds of millions of people worldwide.

 We do a poor job of recognizing the problem, but we're trying to do better than before.

 Before we get started, note that all of your results are confidential and will not be shared.
We want to know a little about you so we can do a better job helping people.
All this information will be kept anonymous and strictly confidential.

We're a small group trying to improve mental health services at schools across the country.

 Knowing a little bit about you would help us a lot in terms of figuring out how to reach people like you better.

 If you share some background information with us, note that all of it is confidential. It will be used to assess what demographics we need to do a better job of reaching out to and help a lot of people in the process.
Are you the first in your family to go to college?
One or two days a week
Three to four days a week
I have a hard time seeing myself making an appointment
I can see myself making an appointment
Yes, and it could stop me from getting help
Yes, but it wouldn\'t stop me from getting help

string-array.name: questions
string-array.item: Do you find that you\'ve lost a lot of interest in things you used to be interested in? This can include hobbies, friends, work, food, or sex. If so, how often do you notice these symptoms?
Do you find that a lot of things are no longer enjoyable to you that you previously found enjoyable, or that you simply don\'t go out and try to do enjoyable things anymore?
Do you ever have feelings of being down or depressed? If so, how often?
Do you ever have feelings of hopelessness?

Sleep is incredibly important for maintaining our brains\' cognitive functions. How much of it we get sheds light on how our brains are functioning. Have you had problems with falling asleep, staying asleep, or sleeping a lot less in the last two months?
How about on the other hand? Many depressed people often have feelings of lethargy and tend to sleep much more than they normally do.
How has your energy level been? Do you feel tired? Drained? Feel like you have no energy to do anything?
One\'s appetite can be a very good indicator of becoming depressed. Have you noticed yourself eating less than you normally do?
How about eating more than you normally do, or binge eating, where you eat a lot of food in a short amount of time? If so, how often?
How often do you have thoughts that you\'re a failure? Or that you\'ve let yourself down?
How has your concentration been? Depression can manifest as difficulty studying or doing homework. Have you had trouble with your concentration lately?
Have you found difficulty finishing tasks you start? If so, how often?
Some people with depression actually feel a sense of physical slowing. Have you felt a sense of physical “slowness” about yourself, like moving slowly?
Other people have said that they\'ve been told they move or talk more slowly when they\'re depressed. Have you had anyone comment on this lately?
Do you ever think about hurting yourself in some way, or ending your life? If so, how often?
How about the thought that you\'d be better off dead or that it would be great to just fall asleep and never wake up?
Would you say you\'ve felt depressed or down for more than two weeks?
In the past year, have you felt depressed or sad most days, even if you felt okay sometimes?
Have any of these symptoms of depression we asked about earlier keep you from being 100% at work, study, or relationships?
Has there been a time in the past month when you have had serious thoughts about ending your life?
Has there ever been a time in your life where you tried to kill yourself?
How understanding would your family be if they knew you had depression?
To what degree do you think your family situation, such as your relationship with your parents, plays or can play a role in your depression?
To what degree do you think your cultural background plays or can play a role in your depression?
Could you see yourself setting up an appointment to go talk with a therapist or psychiatrist about depression?
Would you find talking to a stranger, even though they are a mental health professional, about your depression scary or intimidating?
How adequate and/or supportive are your school\'s mental health resources?

resources.string: Are you sure you want to quit? You can still take the quiz without submitting anything.
Are you sure you want to quit?
Do you want to return to the home screen now?
A score of %1$d is compatible with %2$s.

string-array.name: scoreDetails
string-array.item:
You currently don't have any signs of depression!

 You're doing well right now!

 Remember to check back in when you aren't feeling so well.
Depression is very treatable but it takes work.\n\n It\'s a good idea to see a physician as soon as possible. This will get you started on the path to feeling 100% again.

You also had a number of red flag symptoms, which are especially worrisome.

 Depression is very treatable but it takes work.

 Make an appointment to see a physician as soon as possible. This will get you started on the path to feeling 100% again.

resources.string:
We have some resources that we think may be valuable for people interested in learning about depression.

 It's worthwhile to examine your score from time to time as depression symptoms fluctuate just like any of your vital signs.

 Also, if you found this app helpful, tell others about it! We hope to make life better on campuses one mind at a time.
